newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Early European settlement found in New Zealand.
newsitem.headline: Early European settlement found in New Zealand.

text.p: Anthropologists and archaeologists believe they have unearthed signs of the first New Zealand settlement by Europeans more than 200 years ago, Television New Zealand reported on Friday.
The discovery was made at Luncheon Cove in Fiordland National Park in the southern tip of the South Island.
Otago University anthropologist Ian Smith said a group of 10 seal hunters were left on the site in November 1792 and built a small house and a ship.
The sealers were there for 10 months and culled thousands of fur seals. Smith said they found a pit which was part of a forge to steam planks into shape for the ship.
Thirty metres (yards) away a piece of metal was found which Smith believes could be part of the oldest house in New Zealand.
He said a second phase of the discovery expedition would begin 10 km (six miles) north of Luncheon Cove at Facile Harbour, site of a seal-hunting settlement of 242 men and two women.
English explorer Captain James Cook had first charted the coast of New Zealand in 1769 but New Zealand was settled hundreds of years before the Europeans arrived by Polynesian Maoris.
